body: üëç

Looks like tests are unhappy:

```
TypeError: mark_success() got an unexpected keyword argument 'confirm_propt'
```

Typo? :)

Also saw this error, which looks a little more serious:

```
assert "Wait a minute" in response.data.decode('utf-8')
AssertionError
```
Thinking about this a little bit more I  think it might make sense to do away with the decorator and provide these environment variables to all operators. What do you think?
^ I would tend to agree with that. I don't realize see a reason not to and as we role out increased support that decorator is going to appear in more and more places.

@bolkedebruin I hit some issues with the mocking approach and found a way to run a task asynchronously.

I think this is good to go now.

Pretty much looks good just a few nits, awesome and speedy work :). I would get one more +1 since this is a fairly core change, e.g. from Paul/Max or one of the other committers like bolkedebruin / criccomini / jlowin .
@plypaul @mistercrunch
Looks like my comments got deleted (maybe due to a rebase?), but I think the super() addition you made in the operators should also be made in the operators in contrib. Also passing tests.

I'm not big on the super call. Inheritance doesn't make sense to me here as BaseOperator isn't meant to be executed. `BaseOperator.execute` is abstract 

At first I was thinking that you could just call a `self.stamp_environ(context)` from execute, but then thought about all the operators in the wild and uneven behavior across operators. I felt like there's something wrong with having to make that call from all operators.

Then I thought that a better approach would be to call `self.stamp_environ(context)` pre-execute from the location where execute is called. Somewhere around here:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/models.py#L1289

Operators that want to log more than just the basics could override `stamp_environ`, call super to get the basics and add on to it some more operator specific envvars if/when needed.
@plypaul wonder if we cover your use case of clearing the MQ by moving it to the start of the executor in case you do not use "num_runs". But we can fix that easily by moving it again.
üëç , rebase needed sorry!

I think the overall approach needs to be updated. Ie. you do not mark a "dag" as a success but your mark a "DagRun" and/org its underlying tasksinstances as a success. As such I dont like "dag.mark_success".

Creating TIs outside a dagrun is becoming a big no-no and I would say it is even worse to do so in a "view" component, besides it is indeed not required anymore since #1506 as tasks are eagerly created. 

All in all, I really like the functionality but please make it DagRun based.
@bolkedebruin The failures are only in certain environments and not consistent. I suspect it is not because of my changes. Can you please confirm? Thanks!
LGTM
Has any testing been done on this? If you're using this with doctor elephant, curious if it works as expected (especially if subprocs are being spawned).
Rather than having a new view, I think it is more intuitive to include the environment configs in the same config view that already exists. Might want to double check failing tests, too.

Failed test is:


Indeed, this has nothing to do with you. Are you rebased to head right now?

I'm going to send an email to dev@ to notify of this, since it will break a ton of PRs due to silly merge conflicts. I will give 1d, and circle back tomorrow to merge this in.
Agree with @bolkedebruin's comments about DAG run vs dag.

@criccomini I'm not sure if I understand exactly what you're asking but yes I tested the Airflow side of this. It's pretty simple since all it does is add some Airflow context information to env variables which can be picked up by the tool of your choice in a sub-process.
K, that's all I was asking. :)

Thanks for feedback @criccomini @jlowin! I agree that it's more simple and intuitive to include the environment configs into the existing view. I'll fix the PR.

And I have some questions:
- Should we display all configs finally loaded, or just the one comes from environment variables?
  I think the former is better, because configs defined in airflow.cfg can be overwritten.
- Sorry I couldn't get it. Did you mean the new file lacks an ASF license as @jlowin said?

Thanks!

Thanks!

@jlowin hey @aoen and I think this is missing a dependency on zope. When I try to run even the most basic command (e.g. `airflow version`) it fails due to an `ImportError` because of `from zope.deprecation import deprecated as _deprecated` on `airflow/hooks/__init__.py", line 66`. I tried installing the most recent version of zope and that didn't fix it. I also noticed that zope is not mentioned anywhere in `setup.py`

We can close [AIRFLOW-257](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-257) along with this PR.
@plypaul No I actually mean non-serialized. The dag files in itself are not so big and we are not pickling for state right? So that raises the question why serialize at all?

Something important to keep in mind -- the current version of `execute_async()` just requires the task key (a bunch of strings) and the command that runs the task (another string, something like `airflow run task`). That's because we make no assumptions about how the execution is implemented, or on what machine/environment, or even when it will be run. Passing a task object to the `execute_async()` method is contrary to that assumption. In particular, there is no guarantee that task objects are serializable.

The `key` should give enough information to load the task inside the executor by querying the database for the matching taskinstance -- I think that would be the far preferable way to implement the desired behavior in a custom executor.
Moved to https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1607

Hi @criccomini @jlowin, it seems that the branch again went out of sync because of recently committed changes. üòû  I will rebase the branch again, if you could prioritise this pr, it will be immensely helpful.

Hey @dud225 thanks! The sla stuff is indeed in need of some code love :). I really would like to see some unittests for this as it is close to the core of the scheduler and this is the area where everyone gets a bit nervous when changes are happening. 

Next to to that, a bit more fundamental, relying on tasks here is probably not the best way forward. We are processing per dag and your approach would consider all tasks first, this can lead to operational issues like waiting for locks etc. In your approach manage_slas is called for every DAG but will scan all tasks for every dag. If that is the way to go (I doubt it) manage_slas would need to be factored out of do_dags to one level up.

Small nit: please correct your commit message (mechanism)
LGTM once landscape check is green. Might get another +1 from Max just in case.
@aoen Agreed. How about now?

> Should we display all configs finally loaded

Yea, I think that's the most intuitive.
LGTM except for the spacing issue. If you correct, I can merge.
LGTM
